Award.AwardTitle: Rational Design of Barrier Films to Enable Rechargeable Mg-S Batteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Magnesium-sulfur (Mg-S) rechargeable batteries are a potentially cost-effective and high energy density solution for use in electric transportation. One technical barrier to this technology is that the electrolyte requirements for rechargeable Mg metal batteries have thus far limited cycle life when used with sulfur cathodes. In this project, the PI will conduct fundamental research on UV light-curable polymeric barrier films for the electrolyte-cathode interface to enable capacity retention of the battery. The functional polymeric films will prevent cross-over of certain reactive species, thus mitigating deleterious reactions and maintaining chemical integrity of the anode, electrolyte, and cathode of the battery. The fundamental scientific knowledge generated by this work could enable advances in new materials for other applications where performance characteristics are influenced by ion transport and ion rejection. Additionally, the number, diversity, and training of the next generation of researchers in the chemical sciences and engineering will be enhanced by the further development of an outreach module for high schools and by the broadening participation of women and underrepresented minority undergraduate and graduate students in research.

This project addresses two fundamental limitations in Mg-S battery development: breakdown of active cathode material by reaction with electrolyte species and passivation of the anode by cathode intermediates. Both issues may be mitigated by preventing the transport of undesirable species across the electrolyte-cathode interface. Structure-property relationships of polymeric barrier films to enable Mg-S battery cycling will be interrogated. In the first theme of the project, self-supporting films will be created by crosslinking of a highly dissociable magnesium-titrated ionic monomer with a variety of difunctional oligomeric monomers of varying chemistry and length. Ex-situ studies will evaluate the efficacy of the films in conducting magnesium cations and excluding anionic polysulfides and/or nucleophilic complexes. The mechanisms of steric, dielectric, and electrostatic exclusion will be independently probed. In the second theme, the UV-curable barrier films will be blade coated directly onto sulfur cathode sheets. Effects of thickness, conformity, and chemistry of the films on full cell Mg-S battery performance will be investigated. The performance of the cells will be linked with the fundamental characteristics of the films.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Magnesium-sulfur (Mg-S) rechargeable batteries are a potentially cost-effective and high energy density solution for use in electric transportation. One technical barrier to this technology is the limited cycle life due to the undesirable movement of intermediate sulfur species within the battery during discharge. In this project, fundamental research was conducted on curable polymeric barrier films to use in conjunction with the sulfur cathode to enable capacity retention of the Mg-S battery by preventing crossover of sulfur species out of the cathode. To further support Mg-S battery design, fundamental research was also conducted on magnesium electrolyte compatibility with the Mg metal anode and Mg-S electrochemistry. Finally, study of the polymeric barrier films also led to advances in understanding of ion transport in polymer electrolytes for other battery types (including lithium, sodium, potassium, and calcium).

A library of crosslinked polymer membranes was created that varied in polymer chain chemistry, polymer chain length, and tethered ion content. These membranes therefore had varying physical properties that allowed us to investigate the impact of steric, dielectric, and electrostatic mechanisms on the interaction of polysulfides (intermediates formed during sulfur cathode discharge) with the polymer membrane. It was discovered that the nature of the bound ion in the membrane (the charge density) and the ion content determined if severe ion aggregation would occur or not. In the event of severe ion aggregation, the impact of increasing ion content was to cause a steric barrier for polysulfide crossover into the membrane that was only partially effective. Use of more dissociable bound ions at higher concentration in the absence of aggregation allowed for more effective electrostatic repulsion of polysulfides. In a full cell battery, the crosslinked membranes allowed the battery to charge to a set voltage, a desirable outcome not possible with the standard glass fiber separator. It was also discovered that low dielectric constant (non-polar) polymer chains have less interaction with charged polysulfide species, that allows for less sulfur to be lost in the interelectrode space.

In the study of the Mg-S batteries, another major outcome was the identification of the self-discharge process. It was found that Mg-S batteries containing any of the common magnesium electrolytes undergo self-discharge after fabrication on short timescales. This process leads to the movement of active material out of the cathode and causes a loss of potential capacity even before the battery is ever used. The results of prior literature may be affected by the self-discharge process, unknown to the authors, and therefore the impact of this outcome on future Mg-S research is anticipated to be high.

The crosslinked polymer membranes created in the project were also found to be useful as single ion conducting electrolytes, which are researched for a number of different battery types. With this platform, the impact of polymer chain chemistry on the conductivity of the single ion conducting polymer electrolytes were elucidated. It was shown that for gel electrolytes, lower polarity polyether chains resulted in higher conductivity than higher polarity polyether chains. Increased conductivity is needed for polymer electrolytes to be a viable and safer solution for rechargeable batteries.

Over the course of the project, three graduate students and fifteen undergraduate students were trained in research methods. Of those, one graduate student and nine undergraduate students are from underrepresented groups in STEM (5 majority female, 2 URM female, 3 URM male). Additionally, a polymer battery demonstration was expanded for use in public settings for interaction with children and their parents.
